Introduction

Adjustment disorder is characterized by the development of emotional or behavioral symptoms in response to an identifiable stressor.  The stressor can be of any severity (eg, moving, death of a pet, cancer diagnosis).  Symptoms must start within 3 months of the stressful event and cause marked distress and/or functional impairment.  Adjustment disorder is a self-limiting condition, typically resolving without intervention within 6 months unless the stressor or its consequences are ongoing (eg, chronic illness, financial hardship after losing a job).

Epidemiology and risk factors



Adjustment disorder is common and constitutes approximately 5%-20% of outpatient psychiatric visits.  Prevalence is higher in patients with a chronic illness or condition (eg, cancer, burn injuries) as well as in migrants and refugees.



Risk factors that may influence the development of adjustment disorder after a stressful event include a preexisting psychiatric condition, adverse childhood event (eg, abuse, neglect), prior traumatic experience, a lack of resiliency/maladaptive coping strategies, and minimal social support.

Clinical presentation



Adjustment disorder occurs in response to a stressful life event, which can be of any severity (eg, failing an exam, divorce, miscarriage).  Symptoms typically start immediately following a stressor and do not require a minimum duration for diagnosis.  Difficulty coping with and adapting to the stressor and its consequences results in the development of â‰¥1 of the following:



  • Depressed mood:  sadness, hopelessness, tearfulness
  • Anxiety:  jitteriness, nervousness, helplessness
  • Disturbance of conduct:  impulsivity, reckless driving, destruction of property, aggression


Additional symptoms may include sleep disturbances, concentration difficulties with decreased productivity, social withdrawal, and suicidality.

Diagnosis



For a diagnosis of adjustment disorder, the following criteria must be met:



  • Development of emotional or behavioral symptoms in response to an identifiable stressor within 3 months of the onset of the stressor
  • Clinically significant symptoms that include 1 or both of the following:
    • Marked distress that is out of proportion to the severity of the stressor
    • Significant functional impairment (eg, social, occupational, personal)
  • The symptoms do not meet criteria for another mental disorder and are not an exacerbation of a preexisting mental disorder
  • The symptoms do not represent normal bereavement
  • The symptoms do not persist more than 6 months beyond the termination of the stressor or its consequences


Adjustment disorder symptoms resolve within 6 months of the stressor terminating (eg, relationship break-up), though they may persist beyond 6 months in cases of an ongoing stressor (eg, spousal estrangement) or consequences of the stressor (eg, rebuilding home destroyed by a fire).

Differential diagnosis



  • Normative stress reaction:  is a transient physical and psychological response experienced by most people immediately following a stressful or traumatic event; the reaction is proportional to the severity of the stressor, does not cause significant functional impairment, and typically subsides within a few weeks.
  • Acute stress disorder:  is also characterized by a transient response to an identifiable stressor; however, the stressor must be life-threatening and is typically associated with intrusive, distressing memories and avoidance behaviors.  The duration of symptoms must also be at least 3 days and no longer than a month.
  • Bereavement:  is a normative response to the death of a loved one that also includes mood and behavioral changes; however, the feelings of sadness are specific to thoughts of the deceased, and the intensity of symptoms typically decreases within days to weeks.  If symptoms of grief exceed what is normally expected in duration or intensity, a diagnosis of adjustment disorder may be indicated.
  • Major depressive disorder (MDD):  is also characterized by low mood, hopelessness, and functional impairment and can be precipitated by a stressful event; however, the severity and number of symptoms (eg, sleep disturbances, anhedonia, guilt, suicidal ideation) are increased in MDD, lasting at least 2 weeks.

Management



Though adjustment disorder is a self-limiting condition that remits with resolution of and/or adaptation to the stressor, symptoms cause marked distress and functional impairment and may improve with treatment.  Psychotherapy is considered first-line treatment for adjustment disorder, and pharmacotherapy is used as an adjunct for severe symptoms.



  • Psychotherapy, along with short-term options such as cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), interpersonal psychotherapy (IPT), or psychodynamic psychotherapy, can help reduce stress, reframe negative thoughts, and build coping skills.
  • Pharmacotherapy is used short-term to lessen severe symptoms.
    • Insomnia:  nonbenzodiazepine benzodiazepine receptor agonist (NBBRA) (eg, zolpidem)
    • Panic attacks:  benzodiazepines


Periodic reevaluation of symptoms is necessary as an increase in number and severity may be consistent with depression, an anxiety disorder, or a trauma-related disorder, which would warrant a change in treatment (eg, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors).

Prognosis



Adjustment disorder symptoms caused by an acute stressor typically subside within 6 months of onset.  Chronic, ongoing stressors or those with enduring consequences are associated with longer symptom duration and may progress to depression, anxiety, or trauma-related disorders.  Positive prognostic indicators include engagement with treatment as well as a lack of comorbid psychiatric conditions and substance use disorders.
